conclusion: Analyze the image and conditions to determine the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface where light rays are transmitted.
The image shows a hemispherical shell with inner and outer surface radii of R and √2R. A parallel beam of light with a cross-sectional radius of R is incident on the inner surface.
The direction of incidence is parallel to the axis of symmetry. The refractive index of the transparent medium is known.
Light rays are incident on the inner surface of the hemispherical shell with a radius of R.
The direction of incidence is parallel to the axis of symmetry, implying that the angle of incidence is 0°.
According to Snell's law, the angle of refraction θ1 is given by sin θ1 = n1/n2.
Since the angle of incidence is 0°, the angle of refraction θ1 is also 0°.
The light rays are refracted and reach the outer surface of the hemispherical shell.
The outer surface has a radius of √2R.
The critical angle for total internal reflection at the outer surface is θ2 = 90°.
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface where light rays are transmitted is given by r = √2R sin θ2 = √2R sin 90° = √2R.
Therefore, the radius of the circular boundary is √2R.
